abstractHtml: If you’re an ASP.NET Web Forms or Client Side developer, the name “JavaScript” may induce feelings of dread or even terror. It’s weird. It’s not type-safe. It’s kind of flaky. It’s hard to debug. Heck, it’s not even compiled! Besides, I have all these nifty ASP.NET controls that take care of all that for me, right? Thanks to client side libraries like jQuery, Angular and others, JavaScript is experiencing a renaissance. It’s evolved from that weird browser language you used to use because you had to, to a powerful tool for creating web applications with richly featured client-side user interface. But it doesn’t stop there; JavaScript is everywhere from server side code to hybrid mobile application. If you’re a .NET developer who’s avoided JavaScript it’s time to jump back into the pool! This session will explain some of the key difference between JavaScript and C#/VB.NET, explain what the major JavaScript frameworks are what they do, and show you how to leverage some simple JavaScript in your ASP.NET application.

title: "JavaScript" is Not a Dirty Word

abstractHtml:
For years, front-end developers have turned to preprocessors like SASS and CoffeeScript to fill in the gaps in native languages like CSS and JavaScript. Although these tools have transformed and enhanced the way we write code, they've also forced us to work in nonstandard syntaxes, bouncing from one compiler to the next as we try to find the perfect build process. But what if there's a better way?

Learn how postprocessors and transpilers can revolutionize your code and workflow. If the idea of writing CSS4 and ES7 code today without compromising browser support sounds like crazy talk, you're in for a wonderful surprise.

abstractHtml:
Have you ever needed to support a scripting language in an application?  Why not use .NET!.

This presentation will cover the basic fundamentals of the CodeDOM namespace.  How to create and use template code, dynamic compilation, and integration into pre-compile code.

We will discuss and review how the power of the CodeDOM namespace can be used to add and extend functionality in an application.

abstractHtml: Can a Credit Card From be beautiful? Well it can certainly be ugly! Shopping cart abandonment across ecommerce sites is > 50%. There are simple tricks that designers/developers could do to make it easier for customers to fill out their Credit Card details. Things like automatically detecting the Credit Card Type or not requiring a user to create an account when purchasing an object. These design patterns and more can drastically improve the checkout rate. I'll go through many ways merchants make it difficult for us to purchase things online, how they can improve them and tools they can use to make the checkout process so MUCH easier. I'll cover both Desktop and Mobile use cases. I'll also tell a few jokes along the way like " A credit Card form walks into a bar.. AND..." (you'll have to come to the talk to find out the rest of the joke)

abstractHtml:
Icon fonts, SVG, single page applications (SPA), and responsive web design all present unique challenges for accessibility. However, when executed properly, there is an opportunity to provide meaningful and delightful experiences for all users, including those with disabilities. I’ll begin with accessibility basics and quickly move to making latest trends in modern web development accessible.

I’ll discuss the importance of accessibility, which responsive web design patterns cause accessibility issues, explore mobile assistive technology, and show the variety of tools available to test accessibility on today’s modern websites and apps.

abstractHtml: There's plenty of information on the web about getting started with continuous delivery. When you start auto-deploying a large-scale app to production you'll find yourself in need of more than the basic setup covered in most tutorials. In this session we will look at advanced scenarios for continuous delivery inclucing automated smoke testing, round-robin deployments behind a load balancer, zero-downtime deployments, and more. We will discuss the best practices that need to be in place for these advanced scenarios to be successful and look at some tooling that can help us accomplish these tasks.

abstractHtml:
Evolving an entire organization to deliver more value, be more adaptable and respond to change quicker than the competition is fast becoming *the* directive for many IT departments. The rise of various frameworks and approaches (Scaled Agile Framework, Disciplined Agile Delivery, Enterprise Scrum, home rolled varieties, etc.) illustrate the fact that there is a great deal of interest and money in the market to help organizations figure out how to manage such a large scale change.

However, a framework is only part of the equation. A framework alone is not enough. There are critical activities that need to be mastered as part of any transformation. This session will discuss these activities and why they are so crucial to success. We will also discuss what happens if an organization does not master these activities.


About Martin

Martin Olson is a Principal with Silicon Prairie Solutions. He specializes in Agile | Lean coaching , training and helping organizations use these practices at scale. Drawing on over twenty years of IT experience, Martin helps individuals and organizations define and execute a roadmap to improve their process. Focusing on continual improvement and metric based decision making, the resulting roadmaps are sustained by the teams that are implementing them, leading to true lean leadership. 

Martin founded the Agile KC (www.agilekc.org) group and continues to lead it after twelve years. In addition he has been a founding member of the Agilehood KC (http://kc.agilehood.org/) who’s mission is to ‘Connect groups and communities to foster collaboration’ in the Kansas City Metropolitan area. He holds an MBA from the University of Kansas and the following certifications: PMI-ACP, CSM, SPC, SPCT. You can reach Martin at molson@siliconprairiesolutions.com.

abstractHtml:
Agile and Data Governance seem like they are worlds apart, but it is possible to implement data governance via an Agile framework. This session provides templates, how to’s and lessons learned.

Undergoing a Data Governance initiative can be a daunting feat. Bringing together data, information, reporting, reconciliations, controls and stewardship into a platform to provide “one version of the truth” for an organization is not a small, or quick task. Agile principles align very well with the keys to success for Data Governance. Using Agile methodology for Data Governance focuses on deliverables that are valuable to the business and continuously introduced into the organization. These are delivered through close collaboration of motivated individuals. Through continuous improvements to the Data Governance process, an organization can remain flexible, compliant, and responsive; and end up with an integrated data governance program that enables the delivery of accurate and timely information for operational or financial disclosure needs.

This presentation provides experiences and examples of Agile Data Governance. During this session you will learn:

· Templates for Agile Data Governance.

· How to’s for implementing or maturing Data Governance using Agile.

· Experiences and lessons learned from hands on Agile Data Governance implementations in multiple institutions.

abstractHtml: Over the years, relational databases have become the proverbial hammer to the storage nail. Tables, rows, primary keys, foreign keys and the always loved SQL. Relational databases like SQL Server have their place, but when it comes to relationships, you can easily slip into a world of unnecessary complexity. Thankfully, there is a better way - graph databases. Neo4j is the most popular graph database in use today. In this session, we'll discuss the basics of graph databases, how to set up neo4j, create your first database and query using the cypher query language. You'll come out of this session with an understanding of why and how you'd use a graph database to solve real world problems.

abstractHtml:
The intent of this session is to give you the background knowledge necessary to kick start your exploration of Data Science. 

An example driven / contextual approach will be taken to introduce:

  • Maintaining a work journal
  • Sourcing data
  • data formats
  • extracting, transforming and loading (ETL)
  • Data storage
  • Libraries for working with data
  • techniques and approaches for exploring the data
  • visualizing results 

Finally, you'll get some pointers to online education, contests and communities to further your learning.

abstractHtml: The problem I used to have when starting a new project was the build tooling. I did not want to waste several hours configuring my build tooling, either grunt or gulp, for my new Ember.js project. With the introduction of the Ember CLI, I can npm install ember-cli and get started with with a new Ember.js project in under 10 minutes. We will cover creating a new Ember.js application, seeing it in action, running tests, including an ember-addon, and exploring some of the other features that ember-cli has to offer.

abstractHtml: There are so many boards you can buy to build "Internet of Things" devices: Arduino, Netduino, Raspberry Pi, Electric Imp, Intel Edison, etc. - and the list is growing all the time! In this session we will discuss several boards, demo a Hello World on each of them, talk about their differences and discuss why you might choose to use one over another for certain applications.

abstractHtml: This course provides a detailed introduction to the Object Oriented techniques identified by Robert Martin as the SOLID principles of software design. Intended for both novice and intermediary developers, each of the five principles are fully defined and explored. Real-world coding examples are provided for each software tenant to help fully expound upon the design techniques. By the end of the session, developers will be able to identify common code smells while applying SOLID programming practices that ensure clean and maintainable code.

abstractHtml:
Microsoft’s premier cloud solution for custom web applications, Azure Web Sites, has brought the DevOps movement to millions of developers and revolutionized the way that servers are provisioned and applications deployed.

Included with all the headline functionality are many smaller, less-known or undocumented features that serve to greatly improve developer productivity. Join Microsoft MVP and veteran web developer Nik Molnar for a whirlwind tour of these secret features and enhance your cloud development experience.

This intermediate session is suitable for developers both using and curious about MAWS.

Great examples will be made available after the session as well.

abstractHtml: NoSQL has exploded on the developer scene promising alternatives to RDBMS that make rapidly developing, Internet scale applications easier than ever. However, as a trade off to the ease of development and scale, some of the familiarity with other well known query interfaces such as SQL, has been lost. Until now that is...N1QL (pronounced "nickel") is a SQL like query language for querying JSON, which brings the familiarity of RDBMS back to the NoSQL world. In this session you will learn about the syntax and basics of this new language as well as Integration with the Couchbase SDKs, including the Language Integrated Query Support for .NET based languages

abstractHtml: Apache Cordova is the open source framework for building cross platform mobile applications using HTML and JavaScript. In Visual Studio 2015 Microsoft is investing in tooling to make it easy to build and debug Cordova applications. In this session you will learn how to create Cordova applications and manage plugins in Visual Studio 2015. Beyond those basic steps you will learn how to debug applications using Visual Studio even running on other platforms such as Android. Finally, you will leave knowing how to write platform specific code where needed and merge it with all the shared code.

abstractHtml: APIs are becoming the integration fabric of the future for everything from mobile devices to thermostats to your car. Building robust, extendable, scalable APIs has caused many companies a lot of trouble. In this session we're going to live code an API in Node in less than 30 minutes, including multiple models, relationships, and access control. How will we do this you ask? We'll use the open source Loopback framework built on top of Express. Why under 30 minutes? So we have time to set up process management and profiling, of course!

abstractHtml: Developers today face an onslaught of data storage applications. Various NoSQL offerings promise performance, scalability and easy development on commodity boxes. How does one get these benefits in SQL Server? What does a SQL Server application built today using the newest features and best practices look like? This session will discuss client applications, new SQL Server features and application architectures to support a modern, high-throughput transaction environments.

abstractHtml:
Software engineers are delicate and need to be handled with care.  Employee turnover is painful and expensive.  As a leader, you are responsible for building an environment in which software engineers can be productive and thrive. 

This session will discuss my ten principles for creating and environment that keeps software engineers engaged, productive and happy for the long term, and helps your bottom line by reducing turnover.

abstractHtml: BIML makes SSIS development faster and creates reusable modules that help you apply a consistent ETL framework across solutions. In this session, we will write BIML and use it to build an SSIS package. You'll see how BIML allows you to avoid corrupted metadata and the tedious repetition of implementing simple SSIS patterns, freeing you up to take on new and interesting ETL challenges. Then we will review how to use it to create an extensible ETL framework.

abstractHtml:
Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) is an architectural style that is driven by the notion of segregating your application in to a read side and write side. 

Domain Driven Design (DDD) is a set of patterns and principals to help developers build successful software in a complex domain.

Event Sourcing is an approach to persistence where you store all the events that your system generates in an event store. To get back to the current state you replay the events from your event store.

If you are going to the effort to use DDD in your project, then you will want to consider CQRS in your architecture. The notion of Commands and Events works well in both DDD and CQRS. And since we are dealing in Events to describe the state changes in your domain, Event Sourcing can be a natural persistence mechanism. In this session we will go in to CQRS and why it is a natural choice for a DDD project. We will examine event sourcing and see how that fits in with CQRS and DDD.

abstractHtml: Regardless of your flavor of Agile practice, an area that gives most teams fits is dealing with the Product Owner. In this highly interactive and entertaining session, we'll explore some great tips based on real world experiences that you can immediately start using with your team. You'll also learn how to get started with Product Backlog grooming, a crucial practice that most teams ignore. Finally, we'll end with a Q and A session.

abstractHtml:
Functional programming is the rage, but you don't need to learn a functional language to get started doing it. In fact, JavaScript has had almost everything you need to program in a purely functional style from the beginning.

In this talk, we'll explore the basics of functional programming - higher-order functions, partial function application, lazy evaluation and persistent data structures. We'll see how a functional style helps you compose logic in a way that's clean, testable and free of certain classes of bugs. Then we'll tie it together into a purely functional style by demonstrating a clever algorithmic game solver.

abstractHtml:
Monitoring Complex Applications Using CasperJS

Learn how to utilize CasperJS to monitor your application in any environment. As applications become more and more complex it becomes critically important to ensure your application is available, not just loading the home page. We may have monitoring in place for our applications that test the individual components, SQL backend, web server, load balancer, web service call, but do we have something in place to ensure all of those components can talk to one another? Using CasperJS I'm going to show how you can utilize your current tests to ensure your entire stack is available, not just up. 

We use unit tests when we build a new application, but why does it need to stop once you're done developing? I'm going to show how your tests don't have to stop being used once you leave your local machine / CI system. Utilizing CasperJS really can make any operations team / support team Hapi because your unit tests are continued to be utilized in all environments.

abstractHtml:
At first, you’re excited. You’re going to deploy that hot new open source technology in your stack. Then you want to change how it’s configured, as well as all of the consuming layers. A year later, you can’t stand to think of changing it, last time it caused a downtime and you’re still not confident it’s fixed in every nook and cranny of your infrastructure.

Come meet Chef, the configuration management tool that flexes to your workflow. It creates abstraction over platforms and reusable, programmatic assets for configuring and deploying any piece of infrastructure. You’ll see real world examples and Chef patterns that help, thus gaining a glimpse of what a continuous deployment world looks like.


Dane is a Software Architect at Cerner and has been using Chef for 3 years. He gets inappropriately excited about systems thinking, DevOps, and Continuous Delivery. A developer who wonderered into ops-land, he woos away the ops folks to the secret joys of automation and programming.

abstractHtml: Clean Code is a philosophy of writing code for the reader of the code rather than for the author or for a machine. Writing code that is clean is extremely important because of the high maintenance cost associated with messy code. In this session, you will learn from industry experts what makes code clean. In addition, you will learn how to write reader-centric code that is simple, readable, understandable, maintainable, and testable.

Writing code that is clean is extremely important because of the high maintenance cost associated with messy code.  In this session, you will learn from industry experts what makes code clean.  In addition, you will learn how to write reader-centric code that is simple, readable, understandable, maintainable, and testable.
title: Clean Code: A Reader-Centered Approach

abstractHtml:
Being a developer (or analyst or tester) is a very different role than managing fellow developers (or analysts or testers). In this session we will explore:

1. Do you really want to be a manager?

2. What are the pitfalls of management?

3. Once you are a manager how do you manage those that were your peers?

4. How do you nurture those around you to excel while growing your career at the same time?

Leaving this session you should have a solid understanding if management is a growth path you desire, what options might be if it is not and how to manage those within your team better.

Do you really want to be a manager?2. What are the pitfalls of management?3. Once you are a manager how do you manage those that were your peers?4. How do you nurture those around you to excel while growing your career at the same time?Leaving this session you should have a solid understanding if management is a growth path you desire, what options might be if it is not and how to manage those within your team better.
title: Climbing the totem pole - from dev to dev manager

abstractHtml:
We talk about refactoring, as if beautiful code is all we need. But

that's only a start. Small services are lovely to reason about

internally, but they push complexity outward. Systems these days

aren't so much written as assembled.


We write some code, our precious business logic, and then the real

work is hooking everything together.

Databases, web servers, routers, monitoring systems, search tools.

Plus the easy stuff like version control, issue trackers, continuous

integration.


Every piece both adds and takes away complexity. Even the most elegant

technology is disaster when we implement it without befriending its

internal concepts, or when we use it for an unsuited purpose.


Join Jessica as she finds both pain and beauty in the complexity of

our systems. Will we ever find simplicity? or is the light at the end

of the tunnel an oncoming enterprise service bus?

Will we ever find simplicity? or is the light at the endof the tunnel an oncoming enterprise service bus?
title: Complexity is Outside the Code

abstractHtml:
Writing front-end code today is very challenging when you have to be resilient and robust in a big corporation. Working on a website that involves dozens of engineers based in three different continents, I learned that the complexity lies not only within the code itself. Allowing people to develop new features and deploy the code multiple times a day, keeping it up and running, is hard to achieve: we want small teams to be independent and not to interfere each other, in order to be quick and happy, but we also want to optimise cooperation when it is needed.

In the front-end world components are very small units of code providing application functionality that are all connected in order to become a web-site.

During this talk I’m going to speak about how we tried to approach to components at OpenTable. Following the SOA principles, we tried to elevate components as services, in order to make engineers able to create and consume them via clear and well-defined contracts and interfaces. This allowed us to put in place the infrastructure to optimise testing and to have hundreds of changes live every day without conflicts.

References:

http://tech.opentable.co.uk/blog/2015/02/09/dismantling-the-monolith-microsites-at-opentable/

https://github.com/opentable/oc

abstractHtml:
A careful design lets you write a concurrent application

without thinking about deadlock or synchronization. Getting to that

design takes a lot of thinking. This session delivers the background

you need to make good decisions about concurrency tools. You’ll learn

what’s available in Java, including how to tune an ExecutorService for

your threading needs. After that, learn how this impacts higher-level

abstractions in JVMlanguages: choose from various Futures, Scala’s

akka actors, and Clojure’s core.async coroutines. Whether you’re

working in pure Java or the best concurrency models the JVM has to

offer, this session will help you make design decisions that keep your

code deadlock-free.

After that, learn how this impacts higher-levelabstractions in JVMlanguages: choose from various Futures, Scala’sakka actors, and Clojure’s core.async coroutines. Whether you’reworking in pure Java or the best concurrency models the JVM has tooffer, this session will help you make design decisions that keep yourcode deadlock-free.
title: Concurrency Options on the JVM

abstractHtml:
A lot of developers have started to believe that hooking Visual Studio up to Azure and pushing code direct from their machines is CD. As much as I hate to say it, it isn't. Continuous delivery has so many more moving parts required to work together.

As we discuss concepts such as config management, orchestration, security, monitoring and logging, this talk will help developers realise that continuous delivery is something we need to continually measure, learn and adapt to make us a higher achieving organisation

abstractHtml: Developing for the web has been ever changing in the past few years. In this session we will take a practical look at creating a Single Page Application that integrates ASP.NET MVC with Angular.js and jQuery to provide a rich user experience. We will take a methodical approach walking through the steps necessary to build a robust, database persisted task application. With this example attendees will have a download available after the event that they can go home with that shows the end-to-end development process using ASP.NET MVC and angular.

abstractHtml: OWIN and Katana are at the core of ASP.NET vNext, giving developers full control over the ASP.NET pipeline. In this session I will explain exactly what OWIN and Katana are and how they empower you to quickly and easily reconfigure an entire web application. Now in full control, you can do everything from injecting custom code (middleware) right into your pipeline to running your web applications without IIS.

abstractHtml: Continuous delivery tooling and processes have come along way…for apps. But then there’s our old friend the database. Databases are absolutely essential to our applications yet they are also much more difficult to integrate into a continuous delivery system. In this session we will look at some technics and best practices for setting your database up for continuous delivery. Then we will dive into defining a process for the continuous delivery of our database and setup tooling to support this process. By the end of the session we will be deploying our database to multiple test and staging environments and finally to production all with a few key strokes.

abstractHtml:
Docker lets us build, ship, and run any Linux application, on any platform. It found many early adopters in the CI/CD industry, long before it reached the symbolic 1.0 milestone and was considered "production-ready." Since then, its stability and features attracted enterprise users in many different fields, including very demanding ones like finance, banking, or intelligence agencies.

We will see how Docker is particularly suited to the deployment of distributed applications, and why it is an ideal platform for microservice architectures. In particular, we will look into three Docker related projects that have been announced at DockerCon Europe last December: Machine, Swarm, and Compose, and we will explain how they improve the way we build, deploy, and scale distributed applications.

In particular, we will look into three Docker related projects that have been announced at DockerCon Europe last December: Machine, Swarm, and Compose, and we will explain how they improve the way we build, deploy, and scale distributed applications.
title: Deploy microservices in containers with Docker and friends

abstractHtml: Every single pixel on your website conveys information. Is it conveying the right information? In this session you'll learn that you don't need a some latte sipping dude in a black turtle neck to create a compelling User Interface. We'll cover simple principles on how you can easily and effectively use Color, Saturation, Opacity, Contrast, Shape, Font, Size and Animation in any application. These principles will make your site easier to view, understand and consume, bringing your code closer to your user.

abstractHtml:
A primer into developing high scale distributed applications using Microsoft's Orleans framework.  Discussion Points:

  • The challenges of building distributed systems using current technologies
    • Developer Skill
    • Concurrency
    • Latency
    • Data Shipping Paradigm
  • An introduction to the Actor pattern and how it is used in Orleans
    • Overview of Actor
    • How Microsoft uses Actor in Orleans
    • Where Microsoft is currently using Orleans in production
  • How Orleans helps minimize the challenges of building distributed systems
    • Developer Skill
    • Concurrency
    • Latency
    • Function Shipping Paradigm
  • Demo of Orleans using Visual Studio and Azure
  • Summation
    • The problems it helps solve
    • How Orleans can be used in your projects

abstractHtml: We all want to work in that bleeding edge, best of the best, ivory tower environment where everything is built in the latest and greatest technology and it all complies to standards 100%. In reality, most of us are dealing with legacy systems on outdated code, third-party applications that may or may not meet standards, and user-driven decisions that fly in the face of all our carefully considered architecture solutions. This session discusses enterprise architecture from a real-world perspective, using case studies and life examples to illustrate how we can make all the puzzle pieces fit together.

This session will provide an introduction to the R programming language as well as demonstrate how R can be used for exploratory data analysis.

abstractHtml:
Domain Driven Design (DDD) is a pattern language developed by Eric Evans for effectively managing complexity in software solutions. DDD has evolved as an approach for conceptualizing your project's problem-space, but as software developers we are also keenly interested in translating those DDD patterns to code. If you have always wanted to know how to get started with using DDD in your projects then this is the talk for you -- offering both an intro to DDD concepts as well as a look at NET implementations of DDD concepts.

In this talk we will first begin with a brief introduction to DDD concepts and principles for those new to this overall approach and then explore various implementation patterns to translate DDD concepts into .NET code. We will investigate implementations for Repositories, Specifications, Entities, Value Objects, Services, and other DDD constructs. We will also discuss some considerations for how to structure your projects and solutions to maximize flexibility and manage the evolution of your domain over time. This discussion will focus less on offering prescriptive guidance and more on helping the attendee in understanding some of the potential trade-offs that alternate implementation approaches can provide.

NOTE: this session is delivered in two parts and attendees are anticipated to attend both sessions of the content.

abstractHtml:
With multicore processors and distributed systems becoming the norm, we need to have the tools and techniques to write concurrent and parallel programs that are correct and easy to reason about. The Actor Model (conceived back in 1977) is a high level abstraction for writing concurrent and distributed applications. The core concept of "actors" alleviates the developer from having to deal with explicit locking and thread management, making it easier to write correct concurrent systems. 

Akka.NET is an implementation of the Actor Model and a port of the Akka framework, that has been around on the JVM for a few years.

In this session I will give an overview of the Actor Model; what Actors are, how they interact with messages and why they are inherently good at solving concurrent programming problems. I will cover concepts such as supervision and why this provides clean semantics for fault-tolerance and leads to systems that can self heal. In the second half, I will dive in to some code to demonstrate some of these concepts in a program implemented with Akka.NET.

After this session I hope that you will have good understanding of the Actor Model and why you would want use it in your concurrent, parallel and distributed systems.
abstract: With multicore processors and distributed systems becoming the norm, we need to have the tools and techniques to write concurrent and parallel programs that are correct and easy to reason about. The Actor Model (conceived back in 1977) is a high level abstraction for writing concurrent and distributed applications. The core concept of "actors" alleviates the developer from having to deal with explicit locking and thread management, making it easier to write correct concurrent systems. Akka.NET is an implementation of the Actor Model and a port of the Akka framework, that has been around on the JVM for a few years.In this session I will give an overview of the Actor Model; what Actors are, how they interact with messages and why they are inherently good at solving concurrent programming problems. I will cover concepts such as supervision and why this provides clean semantics for fault-tolerance and leads to systems that can self heal. In the second half, I will dive in to some code to demonstrate some of these concepts in a program implemented with Akka.NET.After this session I hope that you will have good understanding of the Actor Model and why you would want use it in your concurrent, parallel and distributed systems.
title: Exploring the Actor Model with Akka.NET

abstractHtml: F# type providers are an important part of the F# ecosystem in that they make data access feel like a natural part of the language. That said, a properly implemented type provider tends to be a bit of a black box where things just work. In this session we'll look inside the box and see how type providers work the best way possible: by creating and using one! The result will be a type provider that lets us look inside an MP3 file to extract the ID3 tags and expose them to the user as strongly typed properties.

This is especially applicable to those interested in or performing contract work.

abstractHtml: Elixir is a (relatively) new programming language that looks like Ruby, feels like Clojure, and acts like Erlang. It is a language designed from the ground up to feature familiar syntax and powerful meta-programming capabilities, all while running on Erlang's robust, massively scalable virtual machine. This presentation will be a guided tour through not just the syntax, but the semantics of an Elixir application, while highlighting some of the key philosophical differences that help make Elixir (and Erlang) applications more reliable than those written in more mainstream languages.

abstractHtml:
Modern users expect more than ever from web applications. Unfortunately, they are also consuming applications more frequently from low bandwidth and low power devices – which strains developers not only to nail the user experience, but also the application’s performance.

Join Nik Molnar, co-founder of the open source debugging and diagnostics tool Glimpse, for an example-driven look at strategies and techniques for improving the performance of your web application all the way from the browser to the server.
We’ll cover how to use client and server side profiling tools to pinpoint opportunities for improvement, solutions to the most common performance problems, and some suggestions for getting ahead of the curve and actually surpassing user’s expectations.

This session covers a wide array of topics, most of which would be classified within the 200 level.

abstractHtml: In 1984 women were at an all-time high for enrollment in Computer Science, at 39%. We’ve seen a steep drop since then. There’s a lot of speculation as to why, but if we want to solve the problem we'll need to stop speculating and take action. I will highlight programs that are working towards gender balance in technology and talk about how to bring them to your community, as well as how to make an impact at a personal level through mentoring and encouraging 360-degree mentoring in your workplace/community.

abstractHtml:
Go is one of the most exciting languages around today. Led by C and Unix luminaries Ken Thompson and Rob Pike (among others), it was announced to the public in November 2009 and has become the tool of choice across many different areas, especially around operations tooling because of the "get things done" attitude of the community and designers. 

Go has the benefit of being a very straightforward way of writing cross platform code which is statically compiled, requiring no additional runtimes to be installed on deployment targets. In this talk we'll introduce the Go language and ecosystem from the perspective of someone coming from a .NET-focused background. In just an hour we'll cover the basics of the syntax, introduce the concurrency mechanism, write a concurrent network server from scratch and look at some of the practices and idioms you'll need to get going.

abstractHtml:
Over the past year, OpenTable have been re-architecting their system from a monolithic architecture to move more towards microservices and small applications. As the infrastructure has changed, so to the logging infrastructure has had to change. Originally we had a logging solution where all logs where based in SQL Server. We then adopted the ELK stack. This allowed us to be able to scale more.

As the company moved into the cloud, we had to be able to scale even more. We decided that we would move to Apache Kafka.

title: How do you scale a logging infrastructure to accept a billion messages a day?

abstractHtml:
Abstract:

At every conference we see folks standing around by themselves, or hear of those that sit in their room when the talks are over. In this talk we’ll discuss ways to get the most out of your conference experience. We’ll talk about breaking the ice, how to be at ease with yourself and how to work the hallway track.

This will also serve as the launch of conf-friends.com; API, and iOS application. conf-friends.com aims to help facilitate popup meetings while at a conference. No more stray “I’ll be having dinner at X at Y; anyone at #hashtag is welcome to join!”


Details:

We all remember how we felt the first time we did something new. We remember having to do something new in public, in front of our hopeful peers, by ourselves. It’s no wonder many folks hide instead of embracing all that a conference offers attendees. This talk hopes to empower folks to “get over themselves” and get out there!

In the talk, we'll share beginner advice that sets a proper social tone for the conference, especially for folks new to ruby conferences. We'll discuss how to engage people both in person and online in order to become part of the conference's flow. The material will mostly apply to conference newbies or infrequent conferencers, but the activities and patterns suggested will benefit the conference as a whole by fostering inclusion.


Pitch:

*Speaker #1 I was one of those folks that hid. I got nothing out of uaergroups or conferences and always felt super awkward talking to new folks. Over the last number years I have “blossomed” and now lead a user group, teach, speak, and attend conferences professionally.

*Speaker #2 I've been very active in the conference community these last 2 years, having attended 15 regional conferences. I'm also very introverted and have worked hard to offset that through systemic actions. It's worked well and I have a large group of friend and contacts, largely met through conferences :). I want to share that joy and learning.

abstractHtml:
Jobs normally performed by well paid workers are quickly being taken over by less skilled workers supported by machines. This is driving down wages and leaving many workers jobless. Unrest has stirred between the upper and displaced middle class and protests are igniting across the country. This all sounds so very familiar. Oddly, it all happened in the early 19th century. Perhaps history is repeating.


As technologists we tend to look at the lighter side of the technology we create. We solve problems and create software to make people's lives easier and reduce the amount of effort needed to complete mundane tasks. We like to think that these optimizations have a net positive effect in the world around us, improving quality of life and freeing people from drudgery. But, what about the darker side of technology. Can we take a moment to talk about the potential problems we're creating? What road have the beat of time and Moore's law fated us to travel?

title: Human Computer Interaction: Dystopian Economics

abstractHtml:
"Meta-" is such a cool prefix. For example, if this abstract referred to itself, which it is currently doing, it would become a meta-abstract, which it just did. Meta-programming is kind of like that - except it's code referring to code. If you're confused right now, don't worry - I'll explain everything. And I'll explain it using real examples of when I've used meta-programming throughout my career. I might even share an example or two when meta-programming made a huge mess of things. It'll be entertaining for you and embarrassing for me.

This session answers three questions:

  • What is meta-programming?
  • How do I do meta-programming in .NET?
  • Why would I want to use meta-programming?

abstractHtml: Injecting custom code into authentication and authorization in ASP.NET has always been tedious at best. AspNet.Identity is a new library shipping with MVC 5, built to replace both ASP.NET Membership and Simple Membership. AspNet.Identity makes it much easier to implement custom authentication and authorization without the need to rewrite core components. In this session I will go deep into the abstractions that AspNet.Identity builds atop of, and show how to take advantage of these hook points to implement a custom membership system.

abstractHtml: Functional Reactive Programming can improve development of event-driven, asynchronous applications. We will explore functional programming fundamentals and introduce reactive programming basics then apply these concepts in an iOS app. The app will use an FRP library and employ the Model View ViewModel architectural pattern to improve code organization and testability. Although the libraries and sample will target iOS, the functional reactive programming concepts and patterns are applicable to any platform.

Protractor is an end-to-end testing framework for AngularJS. It allows developers to write tests using the same frameworks they do for unit testing. However, it will run inside the browser, as if a user were actually using the site.


This talk will cover some of the basics of Protractor, as well as discussing how Protractor can fit into your workflow on Angular applications.

abstractHtml:
The first stage of any IoT implementation is the selection and integration of physical devices.

In these session we get deep into the bits and bites that power your devices. Not your phone or tablet; The real devices that drive business operations: scanners, health monitors, PLCs, drones, lasers, etc...

Leveraging the primary protocols of device communication and tools for accelerating development, we will connect a physical device and micro-controller to the cloud to start IoT communications. After connecting our device to the cloud, we'll dig into service bus and streaming data to see how these tools can make decisions and control bi-directional data feeds to make machines respond to data in the cloud.

abstractHtml: The ability to run ReactJS code on the server gives a number of unique benefits. It's simple to preprocess single page applications to speed up page loads and increase performance. It's also possible to create more complex isomorphic applications that change their state consistently on both the server and client. In this talk, we'll cover a simple single page application that maintains the same behavior when you disable Javascript in the browser.

All of these topics will be covered in detail with examples and simple explanations.  If you know JavaScript but don't completely understand all of its features, this talk is for you.

abstractHtml:
Have you thought about moving up the corporate ladder - taking your career to the next level?  Does more responsibility (and possibly more salary) sound interesting?  Does management sound like the only way to continue to move forward in your career?

How do you feel about meetings?

A management position can be a fun and rewarding opportunity for some people, while for others it's a nightmare that can't end soon enough.  Many developers have stepped into a leadership role just to find that they don't like being responsible for other people.

if you're wondering if management is the right direction for your career, this session is for you.

abstractHtml: Your website is unresponsive, your cookie size is through the roof. Your competitors have come out with native apps which are flashy and zippy, and they’re eating into your market share. Is it time to drop your website for a native application? Instead of abandoning the web, wouldn’t it be great if you could just spawn a background thread to increase responsiveness, delete some of those cookies and store preferences on the filesystem, and access the accelerometer to get that nifty parallax motion effect — all from the browser? In this talk, you’ll learn to do just that — to spawn threads, save local settings, store your site’s code locally, access a camera and microphone, read accelerometer data, and more! You’ll not only see code samples, but you’ll see working examples designed to get your site off the ground.

abstractHtml: I know what you're thinking: another JavaScript client framework? [insert joke about how many JS frameworks were released while reading this abstract] But I think this one is different. Better. It offers an amazing data binding engine coupled with rich conventions that eliminate a lot of boiler plate code and makes it incredibly easy to get powerful applications out the door fast. Built entirely on EcmaScript 6 and 7 (transpiled and polyfilled to work with all evergreen browsers), support for custom elements, attached behaviors, a rich and flexible router with a powerful and accessible screen activation lifecycle, Aurelia is the most forward-thinking, complete framework out there. In short: Aurelia is everything I've been looking for in a client framework, and in this session, I'll give you the basics to get you started building apps with it.

abstractHtml:
The First Lego League MindSTEMS discuss their experience building and programming Lego Mindstorms, the First Lego League program, and getting women and girls into STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math). The MindSTEMS first joined FLL as Team Lawrence two years ago. They evolved into the Hot Shots, after firefighters specifically trained to fight wildfires. They won an award for their Presentation, and got some practice at Kansas University's Engineering Expo (winning gold), and came back the next year as the MindSTEMs. The problem for 2014 was learning, and the MindSTEMs dedicated themselves to finding a way to get girls their own age into STEM. They will share with you all about programming for Mindstorms, getting involved with First Lego League, and what they learned about women in STEM.

This session will be led by the middle school girls that represent their team.

abstractHtml:
Have your Agile practices become stale or redundant? Does it feel like your team is just going through the motions? Have team members asked to discontinue “critical Agile practices” and ceremonies? 

In Lean product development, the minimum viable product or MVP, is defined as the product with the highest return on investment versus risk. It’s a strategy to avoid building products that customers don’t need or want by maximizing our learning of what is valuable to the customer.

Agile is typically learned through exposure to a series of Agile practices, a recipe of sorts. But what if that recipe goes beyond minimal? Have we replaced heavy waterfall process with heavy Agile process?

This session will interrogate the thinking behind some of the Agile sacred cows like detailed sprint planning, detailed release planning, and even some popular estimation techniques. We will try to identify what is truly needed to be Agile, based on needs instead of prescribed recipes. What is minimally sufficient to start realizing the benefits of Agile?

What is your MVA? It might be different than you think!

abstractHtml: Have you ever started building a REST API just to realize your building a glorified CRUD application.  There are better ways to spend your time than writing plumbing code while possibly introducing bugs.  An OData endpoint can handle all your CRUD operations for you while Breeze.js allows you to query it from the client side with LINQ style queries.  Streamline your REST API with OData. Learn how to utilize it. See how to apply it in real world applications.

abstractHtml: Nothing gets DBAs more riled up than a developer infatuated with an Object-Relational Mapper. ORMs work great at mapping from relational to objects, but can be a crutch. If you want to make your DBA (and your users happy), you’ll want to use your ORM intelligently. In this session, we’ll look at application patterns, ORM features and more to discover the right way of using your ORM. We’ll also look at when to ditch your heavyweight ORM and reach for a lighter one. Finally, we’ll cover why abstracting your ORM is evil and alternatives that give us more flexibility and maintainability in the long run.

abstractHtml: A list of keys, and a delegate: given a dictionary, return a Task. It is a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt over so small a thing. Yet from humble beginnings more than four years ago, we have an open web standard for .NET that the community and Microsoft have fully embraced. From hosting with Katana or Helios to new frameworks and middleware free from the legacy of System.Web, the future of .NET web development will look much different from its past. This session will give a brief overview of OWIN and the current landscape, discuss its implications for .NET web application design, and review a real-world example of OWIN in action.

abstractHtml: Do your organization's reports consist mostly of giant tables of data? Perhaps you have gotten as far as adding KPI indicators or conditional highlighting to the tables. Although tables of data presented as reports are commonly found in many organizations, they may be doing you and your users a disservice. You should optimize your data viz just as you optimize your databases. Reports are a user interface that must be purposefully designed to help users achieve their goal of making informed decisions. In this session, we'll review some data viz best practices and apply those concepts to the use of Microsoft reporting tools such as Excel, Power View, and Reporting Services (although they are relevant on any data viz tool). You'll leave with guidance on how to take boring, unreadable tables of data and turn them into useful and visually appealing reports.

abstractHtml: Are you building apps in Angular, Backbone, Knockout, or Ember today? Well come hang out with the new kid on the block! React with Flux offers a variety of novel ideas that will completely change the way you look at client-side development. Virtual DOM, Isomorphic rendering, unidirectional data flows, and JSX are just a few of the unique features we’ll explore. In this session we’ll learn the core concepts by dissecting an application that puts these unique selling points to work. Many of the largest websites in the world are using React including Facebook, Paypal, Netflix, and The New York Times. And in this session, you’ll see why.

The Regular Expression is one of the most powerful, yet least understood features of any programing language. In this session, we'll cover:

The basic internals of the Regex engine:

  • Regex Gotchas, Tips and Tricks
  • How to format your regexes to be much more programmer friendly
  • Input data validation
  • When to use code instead of regexes
  • Regular expression tools
  • How to save boat loads of time with complex text manipulation

While the some of the demos will use Visual Studio, the session is intended for developers of all languages that support Regular Expressions, regardless of their familiarity with the subject.

abstractHtml:
Abstract:

Talent shortages, better quality of life, and rare skillsets. All these are reasons you might run a distributed team, now we'll help you make it work.

How do you manage distributed teams? How do you pair? How do you grow? How do you become friends? How can you mentor remotely? How can you manage remotely? Distributed teams face unique challenges in communication, technical growth, and bonding. We'll tackle the hard and soft sides of this increasingly important challenge.


Details:

This talk tackles issues witnessed while in various distributed teams over our combined five years of remote working.

Topics will engage in-house engineers to those who've been working remotely for some time. The talk will be a 60/40 split of people skills/tools and technical matters; from little nuances to critical obstacles.


Pitch:

*Speaker #1 I’ve been in the industry for over fifteen years and have worked remotely with teams in the startup, consulting, engineering, and hosting industries. I am also a professor and have taught remotely for over three years. 

*Speaker #2 I've been a full time remote developer for two different organizations, starting back in 2013. As someone coming from non-traditional CS background, I'm interested in analyzing the patterns that make distributed teams thrive or wilt. And want to share those observations with Ruby On Ales.

abstractHtml:
Retrospectives are the engine that fuels team improvement. However, even the best teams can let their retrospectives go stale, and start missing out on the value. Shaking up the process to drive continuous improvement can make the difference between ‘doing Scrum’ and being a truly agile organization. 

In this session, we’ll look at some techniques you can use to keep your retros fresh.  We'll go beyond the traditional formats, and find ways to bring out new insights.  Most importantly, we'll talk about building a team culture where no idea is to crazy to try.

abstractHtml:
The enemy. Knowing it is in your project keeps you up at night. You can feel the technical debt accumulating. There are files in your code base developers are afraid to modify. Training programmers on a new project is taking longer than it should. You feel like you are bailing water out of a boat in a rainstorm. What is this force of destruction that grows like blight in your source? Complexity! 


Complexity is the enemy.


This talk is two-fold: Seek and Destroy.


Seek:

What tooling and practices can help me find complexity? Where does it gather? What are things like SLOC, Halstead Complxity, and Linting? What are some sure signs a file is going to blow up and no longer be maintainable? Working in your project needs to feel like coding with X-ray vision.


Destroy:

Once you find the complexity, you gotta do something about it. We will discuss techniques promote simpler, modular systems. This is both in the form of project organization as well as some useful design patterns. We will look at ways to refactor code into simplicity, by avoiding code gestures that objectively speaking, increase the complexity of a code base.

abstractHtml:
Agile teams face a conundrum. There is always more work to do than they can ever deliver. The pressure is to spend as much time contributing as an individual (coding, testing, etc.) to try and get as much done as possible to help the team meet their goals. Any time spent doing something else is considered as waste to the individual.

Leveraging Lean concepts and scientific research on individual/team behaviors and queue management, Matt will discuss how maximizing individual behavior in a team setting can actually reduce productivity.  Methods to increase productivity will be introduced to help teams achieve delivery at a sustainable pace.

Any time spent doing something else is considered as waste to the individual.Leveraging Lean concepts and scientific research on individual/team behaviors and queue management, Matt will discuss how maximizing individual behavior in a team setting can actually reduce productivity.  Methods to increase productivity will be introduced to help teams achieve delivery at a sustainable pace.
title: Slow Down to Speed Up - It's All About Delivery

abstractHtml: Making the right decisions for a mobile project can be a very involved process of trial and error before you find a good fit. Wouldn't it be nice if you had a map? In this session we will compare frameworks and approaches based on the kind of mobile project you are doing, and walk through what the actual code looks like to accomplish basic tasks for each one. We will cover native, hybrid and mobile web approaches for enterprise-level solutions.

abstractHtml: Everybody's talking about it... you know you should be using it... but you don't feel sassy enough? Don't worry! In this session we'll cover the very basics of Sass and Compass. You'll learn about Sass variables, nesting, mixins, color functions and more. You'll also learn many of the great mixins and functions provided by Compass so you can stop worrying about those silly browser prefixes and sprite map nonsense.

abstractHtml: If you've read the literature on functional programming, you've likely heard of monads. Unfortunately, most attempts to explain them lead to more questions than answers. In actuality, monads are a simple pattern that give the programmer great power by eliminating entire classes of errors and dramatically reducing boilerplate. Whether you're a functional programmer or not, monads will allow you to write cleaner programs with fewer lines of code. Join us as we discuss a few of the most common monads and show how they can improve both your client- and server-side code. In fact, once you see them in action, monads might become your new favorite tool.

abstractHtml:
There's no more hated phrase to an entrepreneurial minded person than "That's not my job."

Conversely, specialists often look upon generalists as people who are "not good enough" in any one thing. The problem is, they're both only seeing part of the picture.

The most successful entrepreneurs will learn as much about a subject as is necessary to understand a task, and then will find the specialists needed to complete it. In this talk, I will help break down the walls of resentment that can build up between the two camps, so that you can be poised for success.

abstractHtml:
I love regular expressions. I *really* do. But they're not always the right tool for the job. Sometimes they're overkill. Other times, regular expressions are just not powerful enough. This is where Sprache comes in.

Sprache is a .NET library that allows you to easily and succinctly define the grammar you need to support. It projects raw text into a fully-constructed object graph in exactly one step. Sprache excels at parsing DSLs, fixed-width data formats, and markup languages. By the end of this session, you'll have an awesome new tool in your toolbelt. And as an extra bonus, you'll understand why the secret of LINQ is monads.

abstractHtml:
Description: JavaScript has made sporadic appearances on the server since the late 90's, but this time, it's here to stay. We'll discuss how we can join the JavaScript revolution and quickly prototype full-stack applications via Meteor.js.

Abstract: There are dozens of JavaScript server-side frameworks (Express, Sail.js, Total.js) but none of them give you the full-fledged integration with the client-side like Meteor.js. Due to this, I believe Meteor.js is the best solution for the standard SPA that needs a supporting database and hopefully, by the end of this session, you'll be a believer too. Feel free to bring a laptop and follow along as we'll cover building a basic meteor application during the session, if time permits.

If you can't make the talk, check out the slides online or hunt me down! I'll be happy to talk about Meteor with you!

Note: As WiFi tends to get a bit finicky when hundreds of people try use it at once, please have Meteor installed before coming to the talk if you're interested in following along during the live-coding.

We'll cover tools, libraries, terminology, and what writing tests can do for you!

abstractHtml:
Swagger for Restful services


Swagger is a specification for documenting REST API. It specifies the format (URL, method, and representation) to describe REST web services. It provides also tools to generate/compute the documentation from application code.


What does this mean? As an application developer, you write web services using your favorite framework, Swagger scans your code and exposes the documentation on some URL. Any client can consume this URL (which comes as XML or JSON documents) and learn how to use your REST web services: which HTTP methods to call on which URL, which input documents to send, which status code to expect, etc.


In this presentation developers would be learning about swagger integrated with Spring boot and Jersey RS.

title: Swagger for Rest APIs

abstractHtml:
Most organizations today are so focused in moving that they are not embracing learning.  The power to improve our product, our work, our environment - all exists currently we just have to be open to looking for it.  We don't need to fix defects, we need to understand the assumptions we made that led to defects.  We don't need to just break silos, we need to understand why silos were put in place first.  If we don't embrace this questioning and learning, then getting training on new processes won't solve problems.

In this session we will introduce attendees to Edward Deming, Peter Drucker, and Peter Senge.  While those names aren't as important, their perspectives on how organizations work continues to open eyes.  

This session will introduce ideas from these thought leaders, provide examples of how this can be seen in our organizations today, and lastly what we can do about this.  Come to this session to stop banging your head around low value discussions (why are there so many meetings? is this a defect, a bug, or a new story?) and move more towards a learning organization that is continually challenging, experimenting, and improving.

abstractHtml: Employees who feel valued and appreciated by their leaders are infinitely more likely to go above and beyond for the company and hold themselves accountable for their part of a project. Most importantly, they will be happier in their roles. If leaders disregard the importance of connecting with employees, they lose the benefit of a dedicated long-term team. During this session we will discuss 11 simple ways to show your employees that you actually care about them. Implementing these will provide you with better employees which in turn will make your projects more successful and that in turn will make you more successful and happy.

abstractHtml: There is a tendency for many of us to try to make everything perfect before letting anyone else see what we are doing. Most of the time this works well, but sometimes we go down a wrong path. This talk is about how to avoid this trap and exchange personal ego for personal growth and excellent collaboration. We'll also examine how to successfully manage the growth of new ideas within a team.

abstractHtml:
Today, more than ever, we’re overwhelmed with a seemingly endless list of technologies to consider. Frameworks, libraries, and even languages come and go at such a furious pace that no individual can possibly keep up. So how do you determine if a technology is worth learning? What should you ignore? When do you stand your ground on a declining technology? Does it make sense to stay cutting-edge, or is there wisdom is being a strategic laggard?

What we need, is a game plan. So in this session, we’ll build a critical expertise for developers: Skill selection. We’ll consider the key metrics, job statistics, market conditions, and lifestyles that should drive your decisions. You’ll walk away with a mental framework for technology skill selection and a clear vision of the values that should drive your future decisions.

abstractHtml:
One of the biggest challenges working with Microsoft Azure is overcoming the "point-and-click around the portal" mentality that still prevails, and writing declarative manifests detailing exactly what resources should be provisioned and the relationships they have with one another. Although the official tooling is moving in the right direction with the introduction of Resource Groups, it still has a very long way to come to match the range of open-source tooling available for cloud platforms that were build with an "API-first" mindset.

In this talk we'll introduce Hashicorp's Terraform tool, first from a high level and then look at the nuts and bolts of how I implemented an open-source provider for Azure that allows the same kind of management style Terraform provides for AWS, Digital Ocean, Google Compute Engine and whole slew of other cloud providers. As well as being a crash course in the Azure management APIs, we'll be looking at the nuts and bolts of a reasonably complex program written using the Go programming language.

title: Terraforming Azure

abstractHtml:
Football players spend a lot of time studying their Playbooks. Coaches spend a lot of time creating them and updating as things evolve. These guys are serious. The stakes are high. In the NFL, millions of people are watching. Their stated goal is to win each game they play. And that means they gotta work really well together and know what they’re doing. 

I think the game of American football is a great example to follow as an Agile team in the business world too. We all need some help with remembering stuff, getting it down so we can execute effectively. Even if we’ve done it many times before, it’s easy to get side tracked; there’s just so much to know and remember. This is complex stuff we’re doing, and in constant flux. We find ourselves wanting someplace to go for reference, clarification, advice, dare I say… ‘best practices’.

I’ve had several clients (both large and small) ask me for something they could use to document the way they ‘do Agile’. If they’re new to the game, they often will look to a consultant or Agile Coach to guide them or help to create this information. 

Enter the 'Agile Playbook'. 

So what is an ‘Agile Playbook’ anyway? 

In short, it’s a helpful guide. It can come in many forms. For now, let’s stick with the football analogy. If you’ve watched an NFL game recently, you’ve probably seen the coach holding up a play sheet, as he decides what play to call. If you (or your kid) has an XBOX or Playstation, with Madden NFL, you know it has a Playbook feature built into it. Team members study the Playbook; it's a useful guide to help them achieve success. Winning or losing depends in large part on having the plays and the strategy down pat, practicing, executing, inspecting and adapting. 

Transferring this idea of an NFL Playbook into the world of Agile software development is natural. I’ve heard it referred to in different ways, like ‘one stop shopping’, or an ‘Agile Coach in a Box’, or ‘How we do Agile here at Company XYZ’. I personally like the term ‘Agile Playbook’ because it’s simple, descriptive, I believe it drives the Team concept. 

In this presentation, we'll focus on what it is, who wants it, and why. I'll give some practical examples of how other organizations are using playbooks and the evolving technology. And I'll share with you an outline that I've used in the past to get started.

abstractHtml: Starting a business is a dream for many professionals, and IT pros are no exception. The draw of independence, self-reliance, growth and profit potential are all very appealing to the right kind of individual. Indeed being a freelance consultant or part of a small company can prove to be extraordinarily rewarding. However, as they say, “with great power comes great responsibility.” Running a software business is about a lot more than writing code. This session will consider the easily overlooked, but ever-important, legal and tax implications of your actions and decisions as a business owner. The discussion will delve into the major issues facing new small businesses. Topics include finding the right advisers; choosing an appropriate business entity (e.g., partnership, corporation, LLC); asset protection for your business and your family; taxes; and how to actually pay yourself. Armed with a bit of knowledge and the right questions, you will be able to approach your legal and tax advisers confidently, empowered to make the best possible decisions for your situation.

abstractHtml:
Software developers have been making estimates as part of their development methodologies ever since the origin of information technology. Agile has been no different in its emphasis on estimation for the purpose of making decisions; in fact, it could be argued that Agile places even more emphasis on making accurate estimates from project inception/planning down to the scrum/sprint level. This mindset is contrary to our natural weakness as human beings in the field of estimation, especially in regards to complex and non-deterministic software systems. Yet the majority of Agile teams continue to place disproportionately heavy weight on estimating scope for the purpose of making commitments and promises, of which we often can’t hope to meet as scope and assumptions change during the development lifecycle. Our natural instinct is to seek improvements to our estimation processes, treating the symptoms but perhaps ignoring the real problem. As Agile/Lean practitioners, have we been thinking about estimation wrong all this time?  

This talk will outline the fallacies of treating estimates as the primary driver for decision-making in software development, and introduce some #NoEstimates concepts aimed at steering the core values of Agile back in the right direction, with more emphasis on iteration and less on estimation.

abstractHtml: Open source tools. We all use them. Whether it’s an entire toolkit, a framework that meets some specific needs, or a simple custom control from NuGet, CodePlex, or CodeProject, it is hard to ignore the opportunity to improve your team's speed of development while learning new things from open source projects. But what does “open source” truly mean? Especially when working in a professional or corporate environment, what are our rights and limitations as open source consumers to use, modify, and redistribute these tools? Often that depends upon the authors’ own decisions regarding project licensing. In this one-hour session, we will review a few of the core principals of open-source development and consumption, comparing and contrasting some of the more popular licenses in use today. We will then discuss both how to use the open source works of others and also how to properly license your own.

Wanna release updates to your website more regularly but aren't sure how?

With Windows Azure, it has become a serious cinch!

Kudu is the little engine that could behind git deployments in Azure Web Sites.

Gain an understanding how Kudu deploys websites.

Learn what's up with the secret .deployment file and what it can do for you!

Discover some of the features of Kudu like Deployment hooks, Web hooks, Web jobs, and Azure Site Extensions. Come and check out how to get your continuous on with Azure and the Kudu Project!

abstractHtml: Over the past few years, I have spent my time on the marketing side of the public facing website team.  During this time there has been a major shift in the approach companies take to their marketing efforts and the content management system, CMS, is the heart of this effort.  Because of this shift, so much is expected from developers to have right at the launch of the site that most of us are not aware of.  These expectations are only going to get worse as we see more adoption of marketing analytic and automation platforms.  During this session, Jeff will cover what is important to have on any website you are launching for public consumption as well as give you some tips to help set your site apart from everyone else.

title: Things developers forget when launching public websites

abstractHtml:
We've all implemented things such as authentication, authorization, login forms, etc., but many developers do so without really understanding what's going on under the hood. We need to know the building blocks of authentication on the internet, as well as their limitations and security vulnerabilities. By truly understanding how your site is handling authentication, authorization, and overall traffic, you can identify areas vulnerable to attacks.

In this talk, I will be going over how to secure your site by thinking like an attacker. We'll develop a thorough understanding of cookies: their usage, how they are transmitted, how browsers are meant to handle them, security concerns, and more. We will also understand how sessions are managed by web servers, as well as security considerations in using them. Additionally, I'll describe common security vulnerabilities that exist when developing web applications and some of the things developers need to be mindful of, as well as how to protect your site from these vulnerabilities. Finally, I will go over how authentication, authorization, and session management is handled in ASP.NET MVC 5.

Additionally, I'll describe common security vulnerabilities that exist when developing web applications and some of the things developers need to be mindful of, as well as how to protect your site from these vulnerabilities. Finally, I will go over how authentication, authorization, and session management is handled in ASP.NET MVC 5.
title: Think Like An Attacker: Understanding Web Security (feat. ASP.NET MVC 5)

abstractHtml:
Imagine you have a data virtualization platform that already has copies of the production data. Imagine that you can non-disruptively access those copies and repurpose them for development and test environments. Imagine all of the hardware and software pieces virtually in place and ready with security and data masking already set. 


Sound too good to be true? In this session, learn how copy data virtualization can work in your DevOPs evolution.

abstractHtml: With the everchanging landscape of devices, web and native applications on both mobile and Desktop, developers are increasingly expected to understand how to create user experiences. UX expectations are becoming more prevalent and sophisticated. What's a Developer to do? Never fear, this interactive and entertaining session will focus on some fundamental UX concepts and terminology to enable you to tackle this new and exciting frontier. Whether working on your own or with a designer, you'll be able to design and communicate more effectively.

abstractHtml:
Writer's block. What is more intimidating than a deadline and a blank sheet of paper? The answer: a deadline and an empty project in your editor.


You need a plan. Actually, you need more than that. You need build tools and project templates. You need the power of streams. You need one command that scaffolds, lints, tests, builds and serves your entire project. You need the power to start developing in warp drive.


Gulp is a task runner built on top of a streaming build system. You can use it to do virtually anything from code analysis, css pre-processing, css post-processing, minification, linting, testing, building and more. Slush is a scaffolding system build on top of inquire.js and gulp. If you can use one, you can use the other, and between both of them, you have a fully-featured clientside-devops technology stack.


If you're a Javascript developer, you won't regret learning about these tools

abstractHtml:
ASP.Net MVC is designed with unit testing in mind. Yet, many developers are unit testing their MVC applications. This is either because they don't understand unit testing or can't figure out how to make it work in MVC. This session will walk you through the whys and hows of MVC unit testing.
You will learn about the following:
    • Unit testing basics
    • Why unit testing a controller is not the best idea
    • How to mock the database
    • Basics of Dependency Injection
    • Third-party tools to make unit testing easier

abstractHtml: Come see a short lecture and live walk through of a demonstration of how to use Java EE 6 Interceptors to annotate a service layer with simple Business Rule Validations.  See how to abstract that crazy business/exception logic out of your service methods and put them into simple-to-use Business Rule classes.  This demonstration will give examples of how to use Interceptors as well as how to test a JEE application that uses CDI and intereception using Arquillian.
abstract: Come see a short lecture and live walk through of a demonstration of how to use Java EE 6 Interceptors to annotate a service layer with simple Business Rule Validations.  See how to abstract that crazy business/exception logic out of your service methods and put them into simple-to-use Business Rule classes.  This demonstration will give examples of how to use Interceptors as well as how to test a JEE application that uses CDI and intereception using Arquillian.
title: Use of Java EE 6 Interceptors to provide Business Rules Validation on Stateless EJB Services.

abstractHtml: It’s a brave new world out there. The new C# compiler (“Roslyn”) is open source, we can write applications for Andriod, iOS and OSX using C#, cats and dogs living together, mass hysteria! The C# language is one of a developer’s best friends, and over the years our friend has grown and matured and become truly epic – from generics to LINQ, lambda expressions to async and await. So what’s next? Join me in this session as we explore what’s in store for us in project Roslyn, and look at the many new language features in the next version of C#.

abstractHtml: We've all read numerous books about software development but seldom do we see what goes into creating the books upon which many of us have built our careers. If you've ever been curious about the process of creating a technical book or are thinking of writing a book of your own, join Dave Fancher as he shares his experience from writing The Book of F# including the time commitment, team interactions, tools, and insights into the writing process.

abstractHtml:
Is your team starting to outgrow the simple $.ajax approach to data access? Are projects like backbone-relational / ember-data / breeze.js appealing but you'd prefer to gain a better understanding of the magic before you bolt on another megabyte of javascript? Join me for an intense live coding session as I build an identity map test-first!

In addition to the JavaScript content, I'll also cover some traditional test driven development concepts in the process

  1. The basics: write a test first that includes the assertion to prove a given behavior
  2. It's all about feedback: you don't need to make the test pass immediately, instead if the error message changes between test runs you are still using tdd correctly
  3. Avoid implementation as much as you can: if you have confidence in your test code (and the test code is implementation agnostic) you can easily refactor your production code as you add new features

title: Writing your own identity map for ambitious javascript web apps

abstractHtml: Are you seeking the Holy Grail of Write Once Run Anywhere app development? Then Xamarin Forms might be what you are looking for. abstractHtml: Google recently changed the landscape of home media with a $35 device the size of a pack of gum. Perhaps more compelling is that this device has made it easier than ever to develop applications for the television. This talk will translate your existing, well honed web development skills into the tools necessary to reach the largest screen in your living room. Green slime will not be included.
